pinoss created branch gh-pages at pinoss/getting-started
Image streaming issues with VLC media player
item.description:
Today i dedicated a good chunk of time learning how to stream raw video using VLC media player. The idea is to work backwards. That is, i want to generate UDP stream from a local image and capture it via Wireshark. Once this is done, i can move towards capturing RTP/UDP stream coming from FPGA. So in a way, it is getting more acquainted with sending video stream and capturing it.

 Here is the relevant post that i tried

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2738228/how-to-stream-your-images-files-with-vlc

after learning the command line of VLC.  Here is what i am inputting at the command line

vlc -I dummy fake:// --fake-file checkboard.jpg --fake-duration 5000 --fake-width 300 --fake-height 300 --fake-caching 40 -vvv --sout "#std{access=udp,mux=ts,dst=127.0.0.1:1234}" --loop

Unfortunately, i am constantly getting the following ERROR


vlc: unknown option or missing mandatory argument `--fake-file=checkboard.jpg'


If you have any experience with VLC or you want to suggest some other tools like Gstreamer or ffmpeg might be better for this, please explain
Originally posted on GSOC 2014

item.title: [GSoC Snippet] 14/07/2014 / UPDATE: 15/07/2014
item.description:
[code] started working with Travis CI, I have some small problems with that, but almost everything works. I will fix them tomorrow. :+1:

[fix]
 fixed Travis CI integration, getting-started build are passing now and are taking only 45 seconds! You can edit and commit changes with prose.io and then push them and it will generate and deploy website in less than 1 minute!
Originally posted on pino IT / ruby / developer

item.title: GSOC ain't your College Assignment
item.description:
Today I submitted my first c code and it was a such a disaster that I am looking back and laughing at it. Contributing to open source comes with it's own baggage like license, coding style and git, all of which I never cared about. But these are very important in an collaborative environment and hence important to learn. I got the bare bone version of my debug program working (with errors) and committed it. But before committing I remembered, "Where is the license?" So I copied the license from a VHDL file ( I know I am a smartass) and then happily committed it, feeling proud of my achievement. Only later I realised that it won't compile because to comment in VHDL we use "--" which will throw a compile error in C. Shenki must have been ROFLing on seeing it.

Also I would like to propose daily tweeting instead of daily blogging. I haven't been blogging lately not because I was not working but blog, don't know why, sounds to  me hard work, like the daily cursive writing my Mom used to make me write when I was a kid.

Okay now I am rambling. Daily Snippet:
-[code]Debug program
-Studied Git
-Studied Linux Coding Stlye Guide
-Sat and wondered why mithro and shenki work so hard?

Tomorrow:
-[code]Debug program
-work on comments and *try* to rebase 


Originally posted on TimVideo GSoC 2014: MJPEG Optimisation

Week 8 Progress
item.description: This week I mostly struggled with porting the custom elements. Though, I successfully ported FGDP producer + consumer components along with the Dirac encoder.

item.title: rohit91 created repository rohit91/HDMI_FIFO_Test
pinoss pushed to master at timvideos/planet
[GSoC] What happenned during last weeks?
item.description:
I would like to apologize, that I haven't written any summarize post during last 2 weeks, but I wanted to end one big part of my project and then summarize it in bigger post. I am doing it right now. :)

Last weeks I spend working with GitHub Issues and Supybot configuration. I did a lot of research and read a lot of articles about organizing work with issues, about supybot configuration, etc.
Then I started working with supybot, after few days I created final configuration for RSS changes notification with Supybot and added it to my GitHub: https://github.com/pinoss/supybot-configuration

After working with Supybot I started working with GitHub Issues. I found nice applications and articles about Issues and I wrote about them here: http://pinoit.blogspot.com/2014/07/gsoc-snippet-04072014.html

Then I started working with Issues, I created some mockups and started creating filter/search engine.

And I created GitHub Issues plugin for Jekyll to download all issues and generated and presented them on Issues page, after that I added input autocomplete for author, assignee and title to make search easier.

Then I started refactoring Javascripts and I changes all variable names in JavaScripts to camelCase, then I was ready to add first filter engine for author, assignee and title fields.

After that I changed _config.yml configuration and grouped rss settings into single node. After that I added new field to config.yml with list of special filters based on labels of Issues and modified JavaScript filter engine to support these special filters.

Then I added few small filters: labels, state, milestones and changed markdown engine in issues to GitHub Flavored Markdown.


Now I will work on Getting Started deployment process, I will try moving generation of website to Travis CI and then integrate that site with Planet. Then I want to fix some small CSS/JS problems and start working with Integration Planet with social media pages (notifying about new posts). I also have some tasks in backlog and I will work with them. :)
Originally posted on pino IT / ruby / developer

item.title: [GSoC Daily Log]:
item.description:
Sunday, 13th July 2014:

  • Spent the writing code for the FIFO based implementation for VGA Capture and Simulation testbench. Watched FIFA World Cup 2014 Final thereafter.
Originally posted on Dreams eXtrinsic

item.title: [GSoC Daily Log]:
item.description:
Saturday, 12th July 2014:

  • Since, even Xilinx’s code for AD9984A from UG458 failed, I’m writing a new FIFO based implementation with independent reading and writing clocks.
  • Day spent in working out its state diagram and starting preliminary coding
Originally posted on Dreams eXtrinsic

item.title: Dirac encoder ported
item.description:
I have been working on components that require some “effects” components to be ported first which were causing a problem. So, I stashed the commits and worked on Dirac encoder which was not much work. As a result, Dirac encoder is ported and I’m getting back to other components.

Originally posted on Porting Flumotion - GSoC '14 Progress Blog

item.title: Working on DDR2/Receiver logic and attending a conference in Tampa Florida
item.description:
Now we need to push real HMDI traffic through Packetizer and Ethernet. I am reading up and learning about DDR2 in my time that i have from attending ISVLSI conference in Tampa, Florida. The other thing that can be done before this and perhaps should be done before DDR2 integration is regenerate the image on the receiver side using VLC or may be GStreamer. This will be done prior to integrating DDR2.

This will be continue on the weekend and next week until get done. Since i am traveling back home, you may not see Friday's blog.

Please tolerate that :)
Originally posted on GSOC 2014
